content.text: PHP Date and Time
The PHP date() function is used to format a date and/or a time.
content.html: The PHP date() function is used to format a date and/or a time.

content.text: The PHP Date() Function
The PHP date() function formats a timestamp to a more readable date and time.
content.html: The PHP date() function formats a timestamp to a more readable date and time.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
Parameter Description
format Required. Specifies the format of the timestamp
timestamp Optional. Specifies a timestamp. Default is the current date and time

content.text: A timestamp is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occurred.
content.html: A timestamp is a sequence of characters, denoting the date and/or time at which a certain event occurred.

content.text: Get a Date
The required format parameter of the date() function specifies how to format the date (or time).
content.html: The required format parameter of the date() function specifies how to format the date (or time).

content.text: Here are some characters that are commonly used for dates:
content.html: Here are some characters that are commonly used for dates:

content.text: Other characters, like"/", ".", or "-" can also be inserted between the characters to add additional formatting.
content.html: Other characters, like"/", ".", or "-" can also be inserted between the characters to add additional formatting.

content.text: The example below formats today's date in three different ways:
content.html: The example below formats today's date in three different ways:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
";echo "Today is " . date("Y.m.d") . "
";echo "Today is " . date("Y-m-d") . "
"; echo "Today is " . date("l");?>

content.code:
";echo "Today is " . date("Y.m.d") . "
";echo "Today is " . date("Y-m-d") . "
"; echo "Today is " . date("l");?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
";echo "Today is " . date("Y.m.d") . "
";echo "Today is " . date("Y-m-d") . "
"; echo "Today is " . date("l");?>

content.code_html:
<?php
echo "Today is " . date("Y/m/d") . "<br>";
echo "Today is " . date("Y.m.d") . "<br>";
echo "Today is " . date("Y-m-d") . "<br>";
echo "Today is " . date("l");
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
";echo "Today is " . date("Y.m.d") . "
";echo "Today is " . date("Y-m-d") . "
"; echo "Today is " . date("l");?>

content.text: PHP Tip - Automatic Copyright Year
Use the date() function to automatically update the copyright year on your website:
content.html: Use the date() function to automatically update the copyright year on your website:

content.code_html: © 2010-<?php echo date("Y");?>

content.text: Get a Time
Here are some characters that are commonly used for times:
content.html: Here are some characters that are commonly used for times:

content.text: The example below outputs the current time in the specified format:
content.html: The example below outputs the current time in the specified format:

content.code_html:
<?php
echo "The time is " . date("h:i:sa");
?>

content.text: Note that the PHP date() function will return the current date/time of the server!
content.html: Note that the PHP date() function will return the current date/time of the server!

content.text: Get Your Time Zone
If the time you got back from the code is not correct, it's probably because your server is in another country or set up for a different timezone.
content.html: If the time you got back from the code is not correct, it's probably because your server is in another country or set up for a different timezone.

content.text: So, if you need the time to be correct according to a specific location, you can set the timezone you want to use.
content.html: So, if you need the time to be correct according to a specific location, you can set the timezone you want to use.

content.text: The example below sets the timezone to "America/New_York", then outputs the current time in the specified format:
content.html: The example below sets the timezone to "America/New_York", then outputs the current time in the specified format:

content.code_html:
<?php
date_default_timezone_set("America/New_York");
echo "The time is " . date("h:i:sa");
?>

content.text: Create a Date With mktime()
The optional timestamp parameter in the date() function specifies a timestamp. If omitted, the current date and time will be used (as in the examples above).
content.html: The optional timestamp parameter in the date() function specifies a timestamp. If omitted, the current date and time will be used (as in the examples above).

content.text: The PHP mktime() function returns the Unix timestamp for a date. The Unix timestamp contains the number of seconds between the Unix Epoch (January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT) and the time specified.
content.html: The PHP mktime() function returns the Unix timestamp for a date. The Unix timestamp contains the number of seconds between the Unix Epoch (January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT) and the time specified.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html: mktime(hour, minute, second, month, day, year)

content.text: The example below creates a date and time with the date() function from a number of parameters in the mktime() function:
content.html: The example below creates a date and time with the date() function from a number of parameters in the mktime() function:

content.code_html:
<?php
$d=mktime(11, 14, 54, 8, 12, 2014);
echo "Created date is " . date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d);
?>

content.text: Create a Date From a String With strtotime()
The PHP strtotime() function is used to convert a human readable date string into a Unix timestamp (the number of seconds since January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT).
content.html: The PHP strtotime() function is used to convert a human readable date string into a Unix timestamp (the number of seconds since January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT).

content.text: Syntax
The example below creates a date and time from the strtotime() function:
content.html: The example below creates a date and time from the strtotime() function:

content.code_html:
<?php
$d=strtotime("10:30pm April 15 2014");
echo "Created date is " . date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d);
?>

content.text: PHP is quite clever about converting a string to a date, so you can put in various values:
content.html: PHP is quite clever about converting a string to a date, so you can put in various values:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
"; $d=strtotime("next Saturday");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
"; $d=strtotime("+3 Months");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
";?>

content.code:
"; $d=strtotime("next Saturday");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
"; $d=strtotime("+3 Months");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
";?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
"; $d=strtotime("next Saturday");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
"; $d=strtotime("+3 Months");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
";?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$d=strtotime("tomorrow");
echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "<br>";

$d=strtotime("next Saturday");
echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "<br>";

$d=strtotime("+3 Months");
echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "<br>";
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
"; $d=strtotime("next Saturday");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
"; $d=strtotime("+3 Months");echo date("Y-m-d h:i:sa", $d) . "
";?>

content.text: However, strtotime() is not perfect, so remember to check the strings you put in there.
content.html: However, strtotime() is not perfect, so remember to check the strings you put in there.

content.text: More Date Examples
The example below outputs the dates for the next six Saturdays:
content.html: The example below outputs the dates for the next six Saturdays:

syntaxHighlighting.text: ";  $startdate = strtotime("+1 week", $startdate);}?>

content.code: ";  $startdate = strtotime("+1 week", $startdate);}?>

syntax_highlighting.text: ";  $startdate = strtotime("+1 week", $startdate);}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$startdate = strtotime("Saturday");
$enddate = strtotime("+6 weeks", $startdate);

while ($startdate < $enddate) {
  echo date("M d", $startdate) . "<br>";
  $startdate = strtotime("+1 week", $startdate);
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text: ";  $startdate = strtotime("+1 week", $startdate);}?>

content.text: The example below outputs the number of days until 4th of July:
content.html: The example below outputs the number of days until 4th of July:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?php$d1=strtotime("July 04");$d2=ceil(($d1-time())/60/60/24);
 echo "There are " . $d2 ." days until 4th of July.";?>

content.code:
<?php$d1=strtotime("July 04");$d2=ceil(($d1-time())/60/60/24);
echo "There are " . $d2 ." days until 4th of July.";?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?php$d1=strtotime("July 04");$d2=ceil(($d1-time())/60/60/24);
 echo "There are " . $d2 ." days until 4th of July.";?>

content.code_html:
<?php
$d1=strtotime("July 04");
$d2=ceil(($d1-time())/60/60/24);
echo "There are " . $d2 ." days until 4th of July.";
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?php$d1=strtotime("July 04");$d2=ceil(($d1-time())/60/60/24);
 echo "There are " . $d2 ." days until 4th of July.";?>

content.text: Complete PHP Date Reference
For a complete reference of all date functions, go to our complete PHP Date Reference .
content.html: For a complete reference of all date functions, go to our complete PHP Date Reference.

content.text: The reference contains a brief description, and examples of use, for each function!
content.html: The reference contains a brief description, and examples of use, for each function!

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Consider this date object: $d=strtotime('10:30pm May 5 2025'); What is a correct syntax for returning the full year (2025)?
content.html:
Consider this date object:
$d=strtotime('10:30pm May 5 2025');
What is a correct syntax for returning the full year (2025)?
